name: steam production, in chemical industry | steam, in chemical industry | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/3394/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of steam used for heating in the chemical and petrochemical industry. The heat is produced with the average fuel mix used in the chemical and petrochemical industry.;This dataset represents only the unit conversion of steam in MJ to steam in kg, with an assumed energy content of 2.75 MJ/kg. The energy losses and water use are taken into account in the upstream process. Even though the reference product is expressed in kg, the exchange does not have any mass, as all inputs and emissions are already included in its supply chain. It can be used as an exchange for a massless carrier of energy.;References:;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

The activity starts with the input of heat required to produce 1 kg of steam.

The activity ends with the production of 1 kg of steam. The energy and water losses are taken into account in the upstream process. Assuming a closed loop of water with the losses already taken into account, no further water flows are included in this process.

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Based on world energy consumption in the chemical and petrochemical industry.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average technology used in the chemical and petrochemical industry.;Two types of boilers are commonly used:;;1) fired tube boilers, which are cylinder-shaped, and closed at both ends by tubular plates enclosing the following items: a large diameter furnace tube passing longitudinally through the cylindrical body, and in which combustion occurs; flue gas tubes (or smoke tubes) in which the flue gas circulate.;Schematic view of a fire tube boiler:;These boilers produce steam and high pressure hot water, and their power ranges from 3 to 20 MWt. They are currently most often equipped with low NOx type burners, which use primary measures for the reduction of NOx emissions (natural gas staging technique or/and flue gas recirculation). ;2) water tube boiler, which comprises many tubes connected to 1 or 2 tanks; the upper tank containing the water-steam emulsion, and the lower tank containing water.;Schematic view of a water tube boiler:;Most often this type of boiler is built specifically according to the power and specifications required. The range of powers starts at 15 or 20 MWt, up to several hundreds of MWth, and even beyond. They are currently most often equipped with low NOx type burners, that use natural gas staging technique or/and internal flue gas recirculation.;Reference:;Zah R., Hischier R. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Detergents. ecoinvent report No.;12. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: This dataset represents only the conversion of steam in MJ to steam in kg. The underlying data for steam production in the chemical industry are described in the upstream process.

exchanges.description: Steam made from water serves as process reactant or heat carrier in many chemical processes. Even though the functional unit is in kg, the exchange does not have any mass, as all inputs and emissions are already included in its supply chain. It can be used as an exchange for a massless carrier of energy.
